sReplication_concept: Repeating a study in a way that there are no a-priori reasons to expect a different result and finding a statistically significant effect (p<0.05) in the same direction as the original finding
The ability of all other scientists in the same field to achieve the same results using the same methods.

A correctly-designed experiment should yield results robust enough so that another researcher/research group performing the same experiment could reach the same conclusion(s), with a similar statistical significance and similar effect size.

Country_of_living: United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland
sReplication_concept: The new experiment shows that the main thrust of the theoretical conclusions of the original experiment is still valid

Following the same protocols, using the same devices, models, and reagents, confirming the published findings
Obtaining a generally similar result if most of the conditions could be mimicked in the replication.

Main_research_topic: neuroscience, molecular biology, microbiology, developmental biology
sReplication_concept: The result in the replication of a single comparison using the methodology proposed in the article goes in the same direction as shown previously. Claims as  "huge" or "small" effect in the original article would require defining windows of size effect for replication. Notably, if the original publication claims the result is valid for "mice", it should be valid for different strains to be replicated. If the scope of the claim is restricted ('C57BL/6 mice") than that is the scope of the reproducibility.
If a Group Expresses higher amounts of a said gene, a successful replication for me is to also see this difference between the Groups, with roughly a similar effect-size.

A successful replication depends on the correct use of controls for each experiment, sufficient number of replicates and individual experiments, all done analysed in unbiased way and with most adequate statistics.

A direct replication means a study using exact the same methodogy of an original study aiming to answer the same question. If original study was underpowered, effect size may be inflated reducing the chance of success of a direct replication.

sReplication_concept: A successful replication occurs when the published experiment can be performed using the article methods only, and the outcome form the experiment must be at least close to what have been published previously.

A successful direct replication is when a published protocol is repeated exactly as mentioned in a paper and results obtained corroborates the original experiment.

A successful direct replication achieves the same results when using exactly the same study design, method of analysis and statistics (even if in a different context of time/space). Achieving the same results, in case, mean that the values of each replication do not statistically vary.

sReplication_concept: A set of experiments performed from an independent and impartial group that reach the conclusion as the original publication in a statistical sense. Material and methods should be the same or analogous if they do not compromise the interpretation of the addressed hypothesis (an electrophysiology study can confirm results obtained from a calcium imaging study for example).
To find, after an experiment, the same differences (or absence of them) that were reported by the original study.
Being able to obtain similar statistical results following the same conditions as the original experiment.

Main_research_topic: Biochemistry, Bioenergetics, Pharmacology, Neuroscience, Metabolism, Behavior
sReplication_concept: In my view, a direct replication of a published finding can be considered successful if the results, obtained from a set of experiments done in the same conditions (materials, protocols, and design) described in a given article, are similar to the original research (i.e., an effect in the same direction and order of magnitude, within the expected statistical variation).
Finding a statistically significant result in the same direction as the original report and with confidence intervals of the effect magnitude overlapping with the original one
The reproduction of the major outcome anticipated. The proximity of effect sizes but not the exact reproduction of raw data, p-values or even alternative hypothesis acceptance or denial.
Results in the same direction and similar size effect compared to the published finding.
find the same main results using the same/similar experimental condition.
Finding a significant result in the same direction as the original study, with effect size in the same range, with large enough power.
To observe the same pattern of results in terms of effect size.
When other group of scientists is able to replicate main effects of an intervention following the same basic methodology
Following carefully the methodology used in previous replications, getting results very similar to the ones reported previously (including effect size and main findings).
